linktype.title: ALT
linktype.description: Destination concept is an alternate representation or model of the source concept

linktype.title: APP
linktype.description: Source concept is applied in the destination concept

linktype.title: CON
linktype.description: Source is a concept that is required in order to define destination

linktype.title: DRV
linktype.description: Destination concept is mathematically derived from the source concept

linktype.title: MTH
linktype.description: Destination concept is a method used in a situation described in the source concept

linktype.title: SUB
linktype.description: Destination concept is a subset of the source concept

node.title: Analysis of Frames and Machines
node.description: This page describes the procedure for calculating the forces between bodies in frames and machines.

node.title: Beam Bending Moment
node.description: This page describes the process for calculating the moment exerted on a beam by various loads.

node.title: Beam Shearing Force
node.description: This page describes the process for calculating the internal shear force in a beam under various loading conditions.

node.title: Beams
node.description: This page describes what a beam is and various assumptions that can be made when analyzing beams.

node.title: Belts
node.description: This page describes belts, which use friction to transmit motion from one shaft to another, and describes how to analyze belts.

node.title: Bodies
node.description: This page describes what a body is, the difference between particles and extended bodies, and the difference between rigid and deformable bodies.

node.title: Bouyancy
node.description: This page describes buoyancy forces, which is what keeps some objects afloat.

node.title: Cables Under Their Own Weight
node.description: This page describes how to analyze the internal forces in flexible cables or ropes that are loaded by only their own weight.

node.title: Cables with Distributed Horizontal Loading
node.description: This page describes how to analyze the internal forces in flexible cables or ropes that are loaded by a distributed horizontal load.

node.title: Cables with Point Loading
node.description: This page describes how to analyze the internal forces in flexible cables or ropes that are loaded by one or more point forces.

node.title: Calculating First Moments Through Composite Parts
node.description: This page describes how to calculate the centroid or center of mass of an object by breaking the area or volume into simpler shapes.

node.title: Calculating Second Moments Through Composite Parts
node.description: This page describes how to calculate the moments of inertia of an area or volume by breaking the area or volume into simpler shapes.

node.title: Concurrent Forces
node.description: This page describes concurrent forces, which are forces that have lines of action that intersect at a single point.

node.title: Connections (Planar)
node.description: This page describes the different ways two bodies can be connected to one another in 2-D or planar systems.

node.title: Connections (3-D)
node.description: This page describes the different ways two bodies can be connected to one another in 3-D systems.

node.title: Constraints
node.description: Ways in which bodies are prevented from moving or rotating.

node.title: Couples
node.description: Two forces with equal and opposite magnitude but differing lines of action that exert a moment on a body.
node.link: Resolution of a Force Into a Force and a Couple

node.title: Cross Product
node.description: A process that can be performed on any two vectors that results in a third vector perpendicular to both of the original vectors.
node.link: Moment of a Force About a Point

node.title: Degrees of Freedom
node.description: The degrees of freedom of a body is the number of independent ways a body can move.

node.title: Distributed Force
node.description: A force that is applied to a body over an area or over a volume.

node.title: Dot Product
node.description: A process that can be performed on any two vectors that results in a scalar equal to the length of the first vector projected onto the second.

node.title: Dry Friction
node.description: The force that opposes motion that results from two solid surfaces in contact with one another.

node.title: Elastic Potential Energy
node.description: Energy stored in the deformation (stretching or compressing) of a body.

node.title: Energy Equations
node.description: The equations that describe the different types of energy in any given system.

node.title: Equations of Static Equilibrium
node.description: The equations describing all the forces and moments acting on a body in equilibrium.
node.link: Solving Systems of Equations Using Matricies

node.title: Equilibrium Stability
node.description: The resistance of an object in equilibrium to disturbances.

node.title: Equivalent Point Load
node.description: A single point force that will have the same effect on a body as the original point or distributed forces.

node.title: First Area Moment and the Centroid
node.description: The centroid of an area is the center of the mass, or force, distributed over that area.
node.link: Calculating First Moments Through Composite Parts

node.title: First Mass Moment and the Center of Mass
node.description: The center of mass of an object is the center of the mass distributed over a volume.
node.link: Calculating First Moments Through Composite Parts

node.title: Fluid Friction
node.description: The drag force that opposes the motion of objects in fluids.

node.title: Forces
node.description: A force is any influence that causes a body that has mass to accelerate.

node.title: Frames
node.description: A frame is a connected multi-component assembly that is rigid and contains at least one member that is not a two force member.

node.title: Free Body Diagram
node.description: A diagram showing a body of interest, disconnected from all other bodies with all forces acting on the body labeled.

node.title: Gravitational Force
node.description: The force that pulls any two objects with mass together. On the earth's surface this force primarily pulls objects down towards the center of the earth.

node.title: Gravitational Potential Energy
node.description: The energy stored in a system by raising an object up, away from the center of the earth.

node.title: Hydrostatic Pressure
node.description: The force exerted by a fluid in equilibrium on any body in contact with the fluid.

node.title: Impending Motion
node.description: The point at which an object is about to move because the forces exerted on the object are on the verge of overcoming the static friction forces.

node.title: Internal Forces
node.description: Forces between different sections of a single body.

node.title: Inverse Matrix
node.description: Multiplying anything by the inverse of a matrix is equivalent to dividing by that matrix.
node.link: Solving Systems of Equations Using Matricies

node.title: Kinetic Energy
node.description: Energy stored in the motion (translation or rotation) of a body.

node.title: Kinetic Friction
node.description: Dry friction between two surfaces that are sliding relative to one another.

node.title: Machines
node.description: A connected multi-component assembly that is not rigid and contains at least one member that is not a two force member.

node.title: Matrix Multiplication
node.description: The process used to multiply two matrices.
node.link: Solving Systems of Equations Using Matricies

node.title: Mechanical Efficiency
node.description: The percentage of input work that results in useful output work.

node.title: Method of Joints
node.description: A method used to solve for internal forces in a truss structure that uses the equations of static equilibrium on the joints of the truss structure.

node.title: Method of Sections
node.description: A method used to solve for internal forces in a truss structure that uses the equations of static equilibrium on designated sections of the truss structure.

node.title: Moment of a Force About an Axis
node.description: Describes the process used to calculate the moment a force exerts around a particular axis.

node.title: Moment of a Force About a Point
node.description: Describes the process used to calculate the moment a force exerts around a particular point in space.
node.link: Moment of a Force About an Axis

node.title: The Moment Intergral
node.description: The general idea of mass or force distributed over space relative to particular point.
node.link: First Mass Moment and Center of Mass
Second Rectangular Mass Moment (Moment of Inertia)
Second Polar Mass Moment (Polar Moment of Inertia)

node.title: Moments
node.description: Any influence with the tendency to twist or rotate a body.
node.link: Moment of a Force About a Point
Work of a Couple or Moment

node.title: Multi-Component Assemblies
node.description: A collection of connected bodies being analyzed together.

node.title: Newton's Second Law
node.description: A physical law that states force is equal to mass times acceleration (F=MA).

node.title: Newton's Third Law
node.description: A physical law that states that for every action (force) there is an equal and opposite reaction.

node.title: Normal Force
node.description: The force between two solid bodies in contact that prevents objects from occupying the same space at the same time.

node.title: Plane Trusses
node.description: Truss structures that can be approximated as 2-D structures.

node.title: Point Force
node.description: Any force applied to a single point on a body.

node.title: Potential Energy
node.description: Energy that is stored in a way that it can be released at a later time.

node.title: Principle of Transmissibility
node.description: A principle that states a force vector can be moved anywhere along its line of action and it will have the same effect on the body it is applied to.
node.link: Moment of a Force About a Point

node.title: Pulleys
node.description: A type of simple machine that allows a cable to slide through it while changing the direction of the cable.

node.title: Resolution of a Force Into a Force and a Couple
node.description: The process of changing the representation of a single point force into force with a different point of application and a couple.

node.title: Screws
node.description: A simple machine that is essentially a wedge wound around a shaft.

node.title: Second Polar Area Moment
node.description: The second polar area moment determines a body's resistance to torsion.
node.link: Calculating Second Moments Through Composite Parts

node.title: Second Polar Mass Moment (Polar Moment of Intertia)
node.description: Dummy Description
node.link: Calculating Second Moments Through Composite Parts

node.title: Second Rectangular Area Moment
node.description: The second rectangular area moment determines a body's resistance to bending.
node.link: Calculating Second Moments Through Composite Parts

node.title: Second Rectangular Mass Moment (Moment of Intertia)
node.description: The second rectangular mass moment determines a body's resistance to angular acceleration (similar to the concept of mass only for angular accelerations.)
node.link: Calculating Second Moments Through Composite Parts

node.title: Shear and Moment Diagrams
node.description: Diagrams that show the internal shear forces and moments over the length of a beam.

node.title: Solving Systems of Equations Using Matricies
node.description: The process of using matrix equations to solve large systems of scalar equations.

node.title: Space Trusses
node.description: Truss structures that must be approximated as 3-D structures

node.title: Spring Force
node.description: A force exerted by a body that has been elastically deformed.

node.title: Static Equilibrium
node.description: When a body is not accelerating, and therefore is experiencing a net force of zero.

node.title: Static Friction
node.description: Dry friction between two surfaces that are not sliding relative to one another.

node.title: Static Determinacy
node.description: A measure of whether or not all forces in a system can be solved for using the equations of static equilibrium.

node.title: Tension, Compression and Shear
node.description: A comparison of three types of loading that forces can exert on a body.

node.title: Tension in Flexible Cables
node.description: An examination of the mechanics of flexible cables, and the assumptions that can be made with flexible cables.

node.title: Theorems of Pappus
node.description: A set of mathematical theorems that can help determine centroids by relating them to volumes and surfaces of revolution.
node.link: Second Polar Mass Moment (Polar Moment of Inertia)

node.title: Tipping
node.description: When an object on a surface is rotated and falls over onto the surface due to the forces exerted on the object.

node.title: Triple Scalar Product
node.description: A process that can be performed on any three vectors that results in a scalar.

node.title: Trusses
node.description: Rigid multi-component assemblies that consist entirely of two force members.

node.title: Two Force Members
node.description: Bodies in equilibrium that only experience two forces, ensuring that the two forces are equal and opposite.

node.title: Varignon's Theorem
node.description: A theorem that states that the resultant of several concurrent forces will exert the same moment on a body as the combination of the moments exerted by all the original forces.
node.link: Moment of a Force About a Point
Moment of a Force About an Axis

node.title: Vector Addition
node.description: The process used to add two or more vectors.

node.title: Vector Decomposition
node.description: Vector decomposition is the process of breaking down a single vector into two or components.

node.title: Virtual Work and Equilibrium
node.description: A method for solving for forces on a system in equilibrium involving small imaginary displacements and changes in the energy of the system.

node.title: Wedges
node.description: A simple machine used to lift or move heavy objects.

node.title: Work
node.description: An influence that changes the energy in a system.
node.link: Work of a Couple or Moment

node.title: Work of a Force
node.description: Describes the work a force does acting on a body.

node.title: Work of a Couple or Moment
node.description: Describes the work a moment or couple does acting on a body.
